questions.question_text: List conditions under which combustion can take place.
hints: Recall the three essential requirements for fire
Think about what is needed for a substance to burn

questions.question_text:
Fill in the blanks.
(a) Burning of wood and coal causes ______ of air.
(b) A liquid fuel, used in homes is ______.
(c) Fuel must be heated to its ______ before it starts burning.
(d) Fire produced by oil cannot be controlled by ______.
hints: Think about pollutants from burning wood/coal
Recall the temperature term for starting combustion
Remember why water doesn't work on oil fires

questions.question_text: Explain how the use of CNG in automobiles has reduced pollution in our cities.
hints: Think about harmful products from different fuels

questions.question_text: Compare LPG and wood as fuels.

Give reasons.
(a) Water is not used to control fires involving electrical equipment.
(b) LPG is a better domestic fuel than wood.
(c) Paper by itself catches fire easily whereas a piece of paper wrapped around an aluminium pipe does not.
hints: Compare properties of LPG vs wood
Consider heat transfer and ignition temperature

questions.question_text: Make a labelled diagram of a candle flame.
hints: Recall the three zones of candle flame

questions.question_text: Name the unit in which the calorific value of a fuel is expressed.
hints: Recall the standard unit for energy measurement

questions.question_text: Explain how CO2 is able to control fires.
hints: Consider how it affects the fire triangle
Recall its behavior when released from cylinders

questions.question_text: It is difficult to burn a heap of green leaves but dry leaves catch fire easily. Explain.
Which zone of a flame does a goldsmith use for melting gold and silver and why?
hints: Think about which zone is hottest
Consider what goldsmiths need for melting metals

questions.question_text: In an experiment 4.5 kg of a fuel was completely burnt. The heat produced was measured to be 180,000 kJ. Calculate the calorific value of the fuel.
hints: Use the formula: Calorific value = Total heat produced / Mass of fuel

questions.question_text: Can the process of rusting be called combustion? Discuss.
hints: Think about oxygen involvement in both processes

questions.question_text: Abida and Ramesh were doing an experiment in which water was to be heated in a beaker. Abida kept the beaker near the wick in the yellow part of the candle flame. Ramesh kept the beaker in the outermost part of the flame. Whose water will get heated in a shorter time?
hints: Recall which flame zone is hottest
Consider complete vs incomplete combustion zones

questions.question_text: Survey the availability of various fuels in your locality. Find out their cost per kg and prepare a tabular chart showing how many kJ of various fuels you can get for every rupee.
hints: Calculate kJ per rupee for each fuel
Organize data in a clear table

questions.question_text: Find out the number, type and location of fire extinguishers available in your school, nearby shops and factories. Write a brief report about the preparedness of these establishments to fight fire.
hints: Check different types of fire extinguishers

questions.question_text: Survey 100 houses in your area. Find the percentage of households using LPG, kerosene, wood and cattle dung as fuel.
hints: Calculate percentages for each fuel type

questions.question_text: Talk to people who use LPG at home. Find out what precautions they take in using LPG.

Make a model of a fire extinguisher. Place a short candle and a slightly taller candle in a small dish filled with baking soda. Place the dish at the bottom of a large bowl. Light both the candles. Then pour vinegar into the dish of baking soda. Take care. Do not pour vinegar on the candles. Observe the foaming reaction. What happens to the candles? Why? In what order?
hints: CO2 is heavier than air and displaces oxygen
Observe which candle goes out first and why
